Detailed Description

Queues of threads are one of the basic data structures managed by any microkernel.

These functions are useful for managing thread queues.

Example of Thread Queue iteration:
tcb_t *tq = mkEmptyThreadQ();
tcb_t *it;

/* Some insertion on tq ... */
        
if(!emptyThreadQ(tq)) {
        /* From the first thread inserted to the last one. */
        it = headThread(tq);
        do {
                /* Operations on it ... */
                
                it = it -> t_next;
        } while(it != headThread(tq));
        
        /* From the last thread inserted to the first one. */
        it = tq;
        do {
                /* Operations on it ... */
                
                it = it -> t_prev;
        } while(it != tq);
}
else {
        /* Queue is empty. */
}

Returns:

tcb_t* outThread ( tcb_t **  tq,
tcb_t *  t_ptr 
)

Remove a TCB from a queue.

NOTE: The TCB you want to remove must be present in the queue. This function doesn't search occurrences of t_ptr in the queue. The result of removing a TCB that's not present in the queue is unpredictable.

Parameters:
tq Pointer to a TQ.
t_ptr The TCB you want to remove.
Returns:
t_ptr, if removed, NULL otherwise.
